document.text: Zt will be a surprise to anyone to receive a letter from somebody whom you do not know and it will be more to you if you will al low me to inroduce myself as just Ralph. Maybe you are wonder ing now who am I. My name is Rafael M. Atencio of a large city in the Philippines. JI am thirteen years old and second year in the high school when the war broke Mrs. J street, ou . I am a son of a dentist in were the city, which was once a beauti ful city in the Orient. My pur pose in sending you this letter is to convey to you all in America how the Filipino boys feel proud of your soldiers where your son, Stratton Franklin belongs. I, as all o her Filipinos feel the grati tude we owe to your beloved country as a genuine liberator of our beloved Philippines from the tentacles of the wily oc opus-like Japan, which sucked the blood and life of our race and crumpled be yond human, endurance the tem- . t red-steel -like patience of the Filipino people. It is but human for me otherwise, not if I not express the, burning seniment from my heart the real apprecia tion of a true Filipino toward the realization and importance of Feb ruary, 1945, which marked the date in the page of the Philippine his ory the sudden victorious thrust of the American forces in the city against the Japanese. It wao abou five oclock P. M. day light saving time, when the first bursting of bombs land bullets heralded the victorious thrust o f the American forces in this city thus the dark clouds of uncertain ty that covered over here for al most four years has been torn in to new dawns of hopes. We have now a real new life! Especially now I have many new and lovely American friends, veiiy kind sol diers they are. One is your dear est ion, Who requested me to write to you. I wish I could be be with him in America! He is in the best of health without a scar nor a scratch, because they al ways won the battle! Let iis pray for them all to win to Victory!

document.text: Xmas holidays passed off very quietly. Lots of visitors came back to spend Xmas with the home folk and some went away for the holidays. Quite a numoer of parties for the younger set Miss Virginia Chick entertained a number her friends at a birthday party on the evening of the 26th. Mis Hazel Taylorwas hostess to the younger set Monday night. The flu epidemic is quite serl ous around here. Some families are ali in bed. The schools wi remain closed until an. 17th on account of flu. Rev. A. I. Caudle spent Sat night with Mr. W. S. Taylor and family. On account of flu there was no services at Hebron last Sunday. Rev. Caudle motorec to Durham, N. C-, Sunday p. m or his family, where they were spending the holidays. Mr. J. H. Elder and family, lrs. G. A. Jacobs and children returned to Richmond Sunday after spending the holidays with Mr. and Mrs. C- M. Stratton. Miss Hazel Taylor left Sunday or Richmond to resume her duties in school. Mrs. J T. Whitten spent part of the holidays in High 3oint, N. C., with her daughter Mrs. Whitten is sick with flu. Mrs. J. W. Neighbors visitec her son, Jim, in Lynchburg few days last week. Mr. and Mrs. W. D. Parris are happy over the arrival of their twins, boy and a girl. Mr. and Mrs- C. M. Stratton spent Wednesday with their daughter, Mrs. D. A. Christian Mr. and Mrs. S. E. Anderson Mrs. C. M. Stratton, Mr. and Mrs. W. H. Drinkard, Mr, anc Mrs. C. T. Drinkard and Cla,yton Jr., attended the funeral of S P. Taylor in Bedford county Monday. Rev. H. B. Jennings Jr., of Leesburg, was Xmas guest of his brother, F. E. Jennings and family. Parks Jennings returned from Richmond Saturday nite after a stay of several weeks. While there tie contracted flu and re mained longer than expected Mrs. Jennings and four children were all in bed with flu when he reached home. Glad to say they are improving. Doctors are kept busy in this community as there is so much sickness. Mr. and Mrs. Clayton Drink ard and Clayton, Jr., returned Thursday from Franklin, where they spent the holidays. Miss Annie Alvis left Tuesday for Farmville, after spending the holidays at home.. She had as her guests Miss Alice Street Davis and Jeffers Street o f Lowesville, and Miss Evelyn Smith of Farmville. Prof. Kenneth Alvis of Athens Ga., visited home people Xmas.

document.text: Xi Gamma Tau Chapter of Beta Sigma Phi sorority met Monday at the home of president, Janet Noble. Faye Stratton, service chair man, announced that 70 of the 9150 goal to purchase a Book Drop Box for the Appomattox County Library, has been collected. Members have been asking Appomattox citizens interested in the library to donate, a dollar or more, toward providing the County library with a facility where patrons can leave books when the library is closed. Anyone interested in donating to the fund is asked to contact Mrs. T. L. Stratton or any member of the chapter to make a contribution. The library pro vides an invaluable service to our community. This is one small way our citizens dm serve the library and at the same time make returning books more convenient for themselves. Xi Gamma Tau announced new officers elected at the previous meeting. Serving the chapter during this coming fiscal year are Janet Noble, president Elaine Stanley, vice president Anne Harris, record ing secretary Faye Stratton, corresponding secretary Shei la Smith, treasurer and Martha Stimpson, extension officer. In other business, plans were finalized for a free Blood Pressure Clinic to be held in co-operation with the Appo mattox County Rescue Squad on two consecutive Saturdays in May. May 8th a clinic station will be set up at Kings in Triangle Plaza from 10 a.m.  2 p.m., and on May 15 a station will be set up at Wilbuns on Rt. 460 from 10 a.m.  2 p.m. Adults, regardless of age, are encouraged to take advantage of this free service, it is painless and takes very little time, yet it can help pinpoint early signs of cardiovascular problems. A couple of moments to check your blood pressure can uncover high blood pressure, a condition which can lead to stroke or heart attack. You owe it to your loved ones, so mark it me- your, calender -uuri-malro-a- real effort to gb. You health really matters! Do something about it.

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. Hudgins, J. H. Lucado, T. W. Moses, Charles T. Moses, Pat Chand ler, L. Crawley, C. W. Smith, W. Stratton Taylor, Jennings Ferguson. T. Ed Owen, W. J. LeGrand, Dr. D. A. Christian, Dr. C. S an- ey, H. M. Burge, R. Travis Lee, F. A. OBrien, R. Edward OBrien, VV. W. OBrien, T. H. Inge, M. C. Imith, S. Guy Smith, R. C Wagner, J. A. Burke, Charlie Johnson, Pit zer Johnson, William Burke, D. A. Conner, D. E. Turnes, Jesse L. Tumes, James W. Caldwell, Harry Jenkins, Leonard Carter, E. Percy Sea, Odel! Howerton, Edmund H. Cawthorn, O. Cleveland Paulette. T. Morton Rosser, R. W. Smith, Leslie N. Ligon, L. E. Smith, C. N. Abbitt, J R Horsley, J. E. Chick, W. L. Brown, L. F. Ferguson, O P. Farrar, J. H. Cheatham, Dr. L L. Gayle, Dr. C. F. James, Robert Hubbard, Fitz Martin, Calvin H. Robinson, George F. Abbitt, Jr., T. W. Ferguson, Lester B. Harvey, J. D. Plunkett. Mr. Gills was first married to Miss Ella Pittman, who died some years ago. Two of the children of this union survive him, Henry Pitzer Gills of Marion, Virginia, and Mr 3 . Luth er B. Pittman, of Richmond. His second wife, who survives him, was Miss Albertha OBrien Of this mar riage, six children wire torn, James, passing away in inf.-ncy. The five living are Professor Allen Gils, of Clarksville Miss Cornelia Kyle Gills, of Appomattox Shelby Ken- nard Gills, of Richmond Mrs. Will iam Haller Copenhaver, of Marion Mrs. R. Banks Frazier, of Richmond. He also leaves five grandchildren, Mrs. R. S. Simpkins, of Chrisians- burg, Va. Mrs. Allen B. Pearcy, of Bristol, Penn. Joseph Pitzer Gills, of Pulaski, Va., Eloise Ogden, and Mary Joan Gills, of Clarksville, Va., and one brother, James T. Gills, of Lynchburg, his only other brother being the late Edmond Ernest Gills, of Appomattox.  And death itself, to him, was but The wider opening of the door Tha had been opening, more and more, Through all his life, and nevei as stiut. . . .

document.text: William Broadua Taylor. 75, Jonesboro, died Saturday night at Johnson City Memorial Hospital. A member of Jonesboro United Methodist Church, he was a member of the administrative board of the church. He belonged to Rhea Lodge No. 47 F and AM, Kerbela Temple Shriners of Knoxville, and served as sales manager of the Dobyns-Taylor Hardware Company for 35 years in Kingsport, Elizabeth- ton, Jonesboro and Rogersville until his retirement in 1971. He was the son of the late James B. and Lula Jones Taylor. Survivors include his widow, Mrs. Zella Lee Walker Taylor, Jonesboro four sisters, Mrs. F. W. Stratton, Alexandria, Va., Mrs. Howard Slaughter, Lynch burg, Va. Mrs. B. D. Stratton, Concord, Va., and Mrs. John Watson, Staunton, Va. one brother, Marvin Taylor, Appo mattox, Va. several nieces and nephews. Dillow-Taylor Funeral Home was in charge of arrangements.

document.text: Wilbur P. Stratton, 75, son of w. D. and Frances Stratton, died at his home near Stonewall Friday night, after a short illness of bronchial pneumonia. He is survived by his wife Mrs. Mollie Anderson Stratton, and three children, Marvin A. and Samuel M. Stratton and Mrs. W. R. Seay. Funeral services were held from Stonewall Pres byterian church and interment was made in the church burying ground. Deceased was a splen did type of the old Virginia gentleman a n d had been a patient sufferer for years.

document.text: Whooping cough is prevalent in this section. Mr. C. M. Strattons little girl has been very ill with whooping cough, so much so that for a time its life despared of.  Dr, Rrice was was promptly called ih,who soon checked the disease, and the little one is now restored to health. Mr. T. J. Stratton State inspec tor and sampler of fertilizers, has completed his labors for the sprjng season. Mr. Stratton reports that fertilizers have been very largely used all over the State this spring, and that he is satisfied that. Appo mattox farmers buy a larger per cent, of their goods direct from first lids for Gash, ilittu tile fui iiiefs of any, other section, of the State. Miss Belle Porter, of Farmville, who is visiting M ibb Lizzie Rice, was quite ill last week. Our people are jubilant over the result of the late election. The old Stonewall district did nobly, and is entitled to the banner. We are for Hoge Tyler for Gov ernor, Taylor Berry, of the old Dem ocratic free State of Amherst, for Lieutenant Governor, and for Thos. lit Martin for United States Senator. Ey r. Chap Jones was in the neigh borhood last Sunday. The Dr. visits us quite often of late. We are always glad to see him, but we cant help but think that there. is a lady stopping here to whom we are in debted for his frequent visits. S tonewall . Spanish Oaks, Va., June 7.

document.text: White summer flowers bank ed with palms and lighted catherdral candles decorated Red Oak Baptist Church June 19 for the wedding of Miss Julie Lee Moore and Edward Thompson Stratton. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace D. Moore of Appomattox and the bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. E.- Marshall Stratton. Jr. of Concord. The double ring vows were read at 800 P.M. by the Rev. Dennis Moore of Chamblissburg.VA. Mr. Daniel Stratton, organist and brother of the groom and Mrs. Ralph D. Reynolds, soloist and aunt of the bride, presented a program of nuptial music. Songs which were sung included A Time for Us, The Twelfth of Never. and The Wedding. Benedic tion. Escorted by her father and given in marriage by her parents, the bride wore a traditional southern belle for-  mat gown of Chantilly lace over a full hoop skirt. The gowq was pi aetihtirVilli  a sabrina neckline and fitted bodice and fashioned with a natural - waistline. The long fitted sleeves were tapered to a V point over the hand. A full skirt r of cascading deep ruffles extended into a full cathedral length train. A Camelot headdress of lace and pearls secured her fingertip length three tier veil. Each tier was L edged in Chantilly lace. She r carried a bridal bouquet of Ljly of the Valley, white roses and I centered with white orchids.  Miss Sherri ONeil Harris,  cousin of the bride, was maid of j honor and Mrs. Neville P,  Moore, aunt of the bride was  matron of honor. They wore a , formal gown of orchid organza  fashioned with a square I neckline edged with a Cluny . lace ruffle elasticized at the  shoulders forming cap sleeves. ! The empire waistline was accented with a wide band of  Cluny lace. The softly Haired  A-line skirt was designed with  a wide flounce at the hemline.  They wore white ripple picture . hats with corresponding orchid 1 ribbon. They carried baskets of pink roses, lavender minature  carnations and purple statice tied with lavendar and piny ribbon. The bride was also attended by Miss Traci Harris Moore, sister of the bride, who was junior bridesmaid. Bridesmaids were Miss Cynthia Lynn Harris and Miss Lynn Renee Rey

document.text: Whistles With Sweet Sounds. If the present plans of the Board of Supervising Inspectors of the Steamboat Inspection Service are carried into effect all craft plying in New York harbor will be equipped with whistles that will discourse sweet music Instead of ear-splitting sounds that disturb the peace of the people In the greater rilty living close to the North and East Rivers. The subject was discussed at a meeting of the Board. Director Stratton of tbe Bureau of Standards said that it was possible, by applying exact scientific principles, to measure the carrying power of a whistle o r a siren, and also to determine the In tensity of lights carried by vessels at night. M t . Stratton urged the Board to  require the use .In New York harbor of whistles giving forth soft, melodious tones, Instead cif those that shriek out hideous noises and make life miserable by day .and sleep Almost Impossible at night.

TO of orman Frozen At His Post. Frank Antonio, a motor man on the Crosstown line in Brooklyn, was overcome by the cold early the other morning while on his way from Erie basin to the barn at Box Street and Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint. When the car reached Jay and Wil loughby Streets, Inspector John Thompson noticed that the car was passing streets where the motorman should have slowed down. The in spector boarded the car and found that Antonio was apparently frozen at his -post. One hand was on the controller handle and the other on the brake, bui th e motorman was powerless to operate either. The In spector took charge -of the -car and had Antonio taken inside, where he became unconscious. The car was raced to the Greenpoint barn, whence Antonio was -removed to th e Eastern District Hospital.

document.text: weeks now Slates of delegates to district and state conventions were elected at a Democratic mass meeting last Fri day night at the court house. The meeting adopted two resolutions one endorsing Watkins M. Abbitt for renomination and re-election to Congress from the Fourth District, introduced by Calvin Robinson and one endorsing the record of United States Senator Harry F. Byrd, in troduced by C. W. Smith. Congressman W. M. Abbitt was present and addressed the meeting. Charles F. P. Crawley served as the presiding officer of the meeting and C. W. Smith served as secretary. The following delegates, instruct ed to vote as a unit, were named to the Fourth District Convention in Petersburg, May 24 J. A. Bingham, George Abbitt, Jr. G. T. Moses, Sr. G. B. Buchanan, J. H. document.text: We were really blessed with a nice rain last week, of which we are all so thankful. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Jennings and children, of Bedford City, visited with his mother, Mrs. Parks Jennings and her family for Mothers day. Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Braford and children visited with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Braford at Natural Bridge, last Sunday. Rev. and Mrs. John Leitner and Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Chick visited with Mr. C. D. Drink ard and Mrs. Wesley Bethel at Oakville last Thursday evening. So glad Mr. Drinkard has return ed home from the hospital and much improved. So sorry our pastor, Rev. Leit ner is on our sick list. Do hope for him a speedy recovery. Mr. and Mrs. Irby Wheeler visited her sick sister, Mrs. Sept Spencer in the hospital in Rich mond Sunday. Do hope for her a speedy get well. Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Burnette and Mrs. Minnie Burnette visit ed with Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lawson and family Sunday! Mr. and Mrs. E. L. Chick visi- ed with Mr. and Mrs. Henry Beard and Lawrence Sunday. Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hedge- path, of Richmond, spent Sun day with their parents, Rev. and Mrs. John Leitner in the parson age. We are happy to know Steve Tanner and Debbie Stratton are both getting better after being sick with measles. Hope they will soon be real well again. Rev. and Mrs. Leitner visited with Mr. and Mrs. Chick and Mr. and Mrs. Rufus Brunette last Monday afternoon. They al ways carry sunshine where ever they go. document.text: We understand that Judge Chris- tain will appoint Mr. Beauregaid Thornhill to be a member of the Board of Supervisors from Stone wall district, to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Stratton resigning. document.text: we try to bring in a speaker to address an issue pertinent to dairy farming in Appo m attox County at each meeting. The Glover farm is situated in an area of the county which at one point contained seven separate dairy operations. There are now five the Glover farm, the Hix farm, the Covington farm, the Doss farm ana the Robinson farm. Marvin recalls that his father went into Grade A dairy farming in 1962. He had been selling manufactur ed milk since 1945 and before that he had been selling cream. The farm has been ui his family since 1907. The Stratton Farm

document.text: We have had real winter for- the last week, snow, hail, rain and wind. Bad i-oads. Mr. and Mrs. C M Stratton, Jr., and Mrs E. H. Carson visit- pd relatives in Lynchburg Sun day afternoon. Miss Mary Connor, of Lynch burg, was the guest of Mrs. Dunkley Gunter for thé week end. Dunkley Gunter, of Lynch burg. has been at home sick with flu for several days. Mrs. E. H. Carson spent last I week in the home of Mr. Carey CerBon and family near Hebron Church. ...Mr, W. H. Drinkard celebrat ed his 80th birthday Sunday. He enjoys good health all the time, just had flu, but has recuperated from that. Mr. and Mrs. H. A. Drinkard and Glenn Drinkard, of Lynchburg, and Paul Drink ard, of Appomattox, visited their father Sunday. We are sorry to hear of the death of Mr. Joe Obrien. Such a good Christian man gone. Quite a number of Lynchburg friends and relatives were here to attend the funeral of Mr. T. 0. Davidson last Sunday. This consecrated Christian man was! an invalid for years and always bore his suffering with patience, waiting to be called to his Heavenly Home. Supervisor S. Ë. Anderson and Mr. J. T. Whitten spent Monday, night in Lynchburg. Mr.. W. D. Sandidge, who has been receiving medical treatment fromî doctors in Staunton for sometime, spent last week at I home, returning to Staunton Saturday. Miss Myrtle Smith spent the week-end with home folk at Ap pomattox. It was with deep sorrow when I the news was spread over the county of Lina Carsons death. I

document.text: We had 105 to register and five. were deferred. There were five first time donors. To donate for the first time John O. Baxter Gayle P. Taylor, Renessa Doss, Sharon R. Cheatham and Phyllis M. Mayberry. Cathryn Godsey received a 7 gallon pin and William  D. Barnes received a 6 gallon pin. Three gallon pins went to Ottoway Guill and Loretta Layne. Dale H, Franklin was a two gallon donor. One gallon pins went to Linda Ruhf, Marietta Irby, Becky Mayber ry, Daniel Stratton, Elizabeth Oxner, Janet H. Morgan, Marvin V, Francis, Wayne C. Jennings, and Leslie Nash.. Thanks to the many faithful donors who helped to reach our goal. Blood is so much needed that I do hope you will come out to donate on our next Visit. Please mark your calendars for our most important visit which will be on December 22, 1981 and our quota is 200 units. You may think this sounds like a lot but with the number of people in Appomattox County this is just a very small fraction. Please do your share and dont always leave it to this same group of donors to keep Appomattox in the Blood program. Would you believe that 536 people are supplying the blood for our entire county? Alice C. Martin, Blood chm.

document.text: Wayne Bowman were conferred the Honorary Chapter Farmer Degree. This award is presented to individuals who have ren dered outstanding assist ance and guidance to the local chapter. It is the highest award that can be given by a local FFA chapter.  Following the Honorary Chapter Farm er cere- mony, proficiency awards were presented to 12 members. Awards and recipients were Tobacco Proficiency  Ray Cheat ham Poultry Production   Richard Jones Forest Management - Dennis Stratton Agricultural Mechanics - Vince McEl roy Turf and Landscape Management - David Doss Extemporaneous Public Speaking - Ralph Totty Prepared Public Speaking - Dennis Stratton Soil and Water Management  Phil Paulette Home Improve ment - Dale Garrett Ag. Sales and Services - Roy Hopkins Swine Profi ciency - Duane Blanks Sheep Proficiency - Tom my Gilliam Beef Produc tion - Roger Walton and Diversified Livestock - Duane Blanks. The evening culminated with the awarding of the three top awards for Chapter members. Star Chapter Farmer was pre sented to Phil Paulette. Star Chapter Agribus inessman was won by Gary Campbèll and Chapter Leadership award was presented to Dale Garrett.

document.text: Watkins M. Abbitt, representative of the Fourth Congressional District, I praised farming as a life work in his address before the 1953 Father-Son Banquet of the Appomattox Chapter, Future Farmers of America here on Friday night. Congressman Abbitt reviewed agri cultural progress in southern Vir ginia during the present century and stressed particularly the improve ment that has been made in farm family living. Farm families no longer need to do without the con veniences city people enjoy, he said. Jack Stratton, president, served as toastmaster for the banquet, attend ed by nearly 100 Future Farmers, their fathers and invited guests. The welcome address was made by Ben. jamin Beasley. Everett Beal, vice-president, spoke on Grass as an Investment. Rep. Abbitt was introduced by Lloyd Walton, chapter secretary. H. B. Pack, Advisor of the Appo-
